Award.AwardTitle: Cyber4All: An Interdisciplinary Cybersecurity Minor for all Undergraduates

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cybersecurity has critical political, military, economic, social, infrastructure, and information implications for our nation. Effective cybersecurity solutions require initiatives that not only prepare computer scientists to be cybersecurity professionals, but extend security education to all majors to produce a cybersecurity prepared workforce. As cyberspace has become ubiquitous, cybersecurity has become everyone's business. A comprehensive cybersecurity education model needs to reach all students and disciplines impacted by cybersecurity issues.

Cyber4All presents a scalable model for Interdisciplinary Cybersecurity education that includes: (1) An interdisciplinary cybersecurity minor--A multidisciplinary team of industry and academic experts will design an interdisciplinary cybersecurity minor that will include foundational security knowledge based on guidelines in cybersecurity education. The minor will also include tracks in critical application areas within the disciplines of health care, e-business, criminal justice, and information technology. This minor will be designed using courses common at most institutions and implemented so all students across all majors can complement their undergraduate degrees with cybersecurity knowledge. (2) A library of interdisciplinary cybersecurity modules? The multidisciplinary team of industry and academic experts will design modules that target core cybersecurity issues that are pertinent to that discipline. Modules will be designed using the Security Injections@Towson framework, which has demonstrated success introducing secure coding in computer science classes. (3) An interdisciplinary cybersecurity ecosystem to build and sustain the curriculum? An ecosystem will be created to include a Cybersecurity Ambassador working with faculty fellows to champion cybersecurity education across the disciplines - health care, e-business, criminal justice, and information technology. Cyber-seminars and workshops will be held to increase faculty interest in cybersecurity, foster diverse perspectives, and promote the minor.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Effective cybersecurity solutions require initiatives that not only prepare computer scientists to be cybersecurity professionals, but extend security education to all majors to produce a cybersecurity prepared workforce. As cyberspace has become ubiquitous, cybersecurity has become everyone’s business. A comprehensive cybersecurity education model needs to reach all students and disciplines impacted by cybersecurity issues. We proposed a scalable model for Interdisciplinary Cybersecurity education that includes a library of inter-disciplinary modules, a design of a cybersecurity minor meant for non-computing majors, and a workshop that builds a community for further discussion on cybersecurity.   

The Cyber4All model produced as an outcome of this project provides a practical and flexible approach to develop and implement an interdisciplinary cybersecurity minor, expanding cybersecurity education beyond computer science. The interdisciplinary cybersecurity minor provides a scalable solution to the immediate problem of providing security education for all undergraduates. This will provide a much-needed cybersecurity mindset to future decision-makers and front-line workers in business, criminal justice, information technology, and health care.

As part of this project, In August 2017, we held the first Cybersecurity Education Workshop. The workshop had 85 attendees for various disciplines, including a focused group of about faculty specializing in cyber/computing curriculum development as well as government representatives. The goal was to accelerate Cybersecurity curriculum adaptation. The goal of the members of academia and government was to collaborate to build upon ongoing multidisciplinary security education programs and catalyze review, adoption, incorporation, and dissemination of cyber security curricula. The event also explored novel ideas, approaches, and experiences.

During the 2-day workshop, there were presentations from educators, panel discussion, knowledge sharing sessions, and breakout groups to enable discussion of ideas for cybersecurity education and how to navigate challenges in the content integration process (e.g., licensing, creation of support material for educators, leveraging public investment in cybersecurity curricula, and teaching to both technical and non-technical students). The workshop generated new ideas for security content adoption and collaborative initiatives among various faculty. It was a successful event that encouraged partnerships and collaborative curriculum development that leverages industry and government needs, resources, and tools.
